G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, as this is a civil action in which the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in Norfolk County pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1, as the events giving rise to this Complaint occurred in Norfolk County.

See *Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693,.proposition: Defendant’s negligence constitutes a violation of its duty of care owed to Plaintiff under Massachusetts law.
See *Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693,.support_reasoning: The quoted concurrence discusses the proper framework for premises liability in terms of classifications of entrants (trespasser, licensee, invitee) and criticizes retaining special rules for trespassers. It does not state or apply any rule that a particular defendant’s negligence constitutes a violation of a duty of care owed to a particular plaintiff, nor does it articulate a general Massachusetts rule that negligence necessarily equals breach of duty. Thus, this passage does not support the specific proposition claimed.
See *Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693,.relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that ‘trespassers’ stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential. This tends to perpetuate, although on a smaller scale, the kind of tradition-bound and mistaken analysis that I had supposed the court was aiming to correct."

*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.raw_text: *Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth.*, 363 Mass. 165, 167 (1973)
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.proposition: Defendant’s failure to act reasonably to address a known hazard also constitutes negligence under *Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth.*, 363 Mass. 165, 167 (1973) (a property owner may be liable for failing to address a dangerous condition that it knew or should have known about).
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely articulates the duty of a party controlling business premises to use due care to keep the premises reasonably safe or to warn of dangers the owner knows or ought to know about. That is the same negligence principle the proposition describes: liability can arise from failure to address a dangerous condition the defendant knew or should have known about. Although the plaintiff ultimately loses on proof of the time element, the stated rule of law supports the cited proposition.
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.relevant_excerpt: “The obligation of one who controls business premises is to use due care to keep the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition, or at least to warn them of any dangers that might arise from such use, which are not likely to be known to them, and of which the defendant knows or ought to know.… In the more usual case, however, the plaintiff attempts to establish the defendant’s negligence by showing that the foreign substance was present … for such a length of time that the defendant should have known about it.”

See *Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets.raw_text: See *Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.*, 448 Mass. 780, 787 (2007)
See *Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets.proposition: Evidence of constructive knowledge, such as the length of time the hazard persisted, establishes Defendant’s liability.
See *Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
See *Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets.support_reasoning: The opinion explains that under the traditional rule, constructive notice could be shown by how long the substance was on the floor, but the whole point of Sheehan is to move away from requiring that sort of temporal proof by adopting the mode of operation approach. Liability in Sheehan is based on foreseeability inherent in the store’s self-service mode of operation, not on evidence about how long the grape was on the floor. Thus, the case does not support the proposition that evidence of the length of time the hazard persisted establishes liability; it deemphasizes that requirement.
See *Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets.relevant_excerpt: “Under the traditional approach to premises liability, the plaintiff is required to prove … the substance, matter, or item had been on the floor so long that the store operator should have been aware of the condition. … In sum, the adoption of the mode of operation approach will not modify the general rule … However, if a plaintiff proves that an unsafe condition on an owner’s premises exists that was reasonably foreseeable, resulting from an owner’s self-service business or mode of operation… the plaintiff will satisfy the notice requirement.”

See *Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457.proposition: Failure to warn invitees about a known danger also constitutes a breach of duty under Massachusetts law.
See *Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly describes the duty owed to invitees under Massachusetts premises liability law and includes, as part of that duty, the obligation either to repair/remove dangers or at least to warn of non-obvious dangers known or reasonably knowable to the property owner. This directly aligns with the proposition that failure to warn invitees of a known danger can constitute a breach of duty. Although the case’s main issue is snow and ice, the court restates the general duty-to-warn rule as controlling Massachusetts law.
See *Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457.relevant_excerpt: “If the plaintiff was an invitee… the property owner owed a duty to use reasonable care to keep the premises ‘in a reasonably safe condition….’ This duty required a property owner to make reasonable efforts to repair or remove any dangerous conditions, or at least to warn against any dangers not either known to the invitee or obvious to any ordinarily intelligent person and of which the property owner knew or reasonably should have known.” *Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass. 368, 371–372 (2010) (citation omitted).

See *Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co.*, 4.raw_text: See *Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co.*, 400 Mass. 837, 842 (1987)
See *Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co.*, 4.proposition: The lack of proper warning signage, such as a wet floor sign, further demonstrates Defendant’s failure to take reasonable steps to remove or mitigate the hazard.
See *Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co.*, 4.support_reasoning: The cited concurrence discusses whether the defendant had a duty to warn customers of the obvious risk of injury from other vehicles at a self-service gas station. It concludes that such a risk is inherent and obvious and that there is no duty to warn of it. This undercuts, rather than supports, a proposition that lack of warning signage (like a wet floor sign) demonstrates a failure to take reasonable steps to mitigate a hazard; the opinion finds no duty to warn of an obvious vehicular danger.
See *Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co.*, 4.relevant_excerpt: “In my view, the risk of injury to a customer from the negligent operation of another vehicle on the premises of a self-service station is inherent and obvious. There is no duty to warn of such a danger.”

See *Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc.*.raw_text: See *Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc.*, 438 Mass. 317, 319 (2002)
See *Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc.*.proposition: Defendant is responsible for the actions of its employees under the doctrine of respondeat superior.
See *Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc.*.case_name: Dias v. Brigham Medical Associates, Inc.
See *Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc.*.support_reasoning: The opinion directly addresses respondeat superior and holds that a corporate employer of a physician can be vicariously liable for the physician’s negligence committed within the scope of employment. The court explicitly states that, once an employer-employee relationship is established, traditional respondeat superior applies and the employer may be held liable for the employee’s acts without needing to control specific treatment decisions. This squarely supports the general proposition that a defendant is responsible for its employees’ actions under respondeat superior.
See *Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc.*.relevant_excerpt: “Broadly speaking, respondeat superior is the proposition that an employer, or master, should be held vicariously liable for the torts of its employee, or servant, committed within the scope of employment… To prevail against BMA, the plaintiffs need only establish that (1) at the time of the alleged negligence Dr. Schlitzer was an employee of BMA, and (2) the alleged negligent treatment of the plaintiff occurred within the scope of Dr. Schlitzer’s employment by BMA.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain a safe premises deprived Plaintiff of the protections afforded by G.L. c. 231, § 85 in negligence actions.

*King v. G & M Realty Corp.*, 373 Mass..raw_text: *King v. G & M Realty Corp.*, 373 Mass. 658, 662-63 (1977)
*King v. G & M Realty Corp.*, 373 Mass..proposition: Defendant’s actions fell below the standard of care owed to invitees and violated Massachusetts common law as articulated in *King v. G & M Realty Corp.*, 373 Mass. 658, 662-63 (1977).
*King v. G & M Realty Corp.*, 373 Mass..case_name: King v. G & M REALTY CORP.
*King v. G & M Realty Corp.*, 373 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion directly holds that a landlord who retains control over common areas (like a stairway) owes tenants and other lawful users a general, continuing duty to exercise reasonable care to keep those areas reasonably safe, abandoning the older, more limited Massachusetts rule. That is precisely the standard-of-care principle the proposition invokes for invitees under Massachusetts common law, and the court affirms the trial judge’s instruction imposing this duty on the defendant landlord. Thus, the case squarely supports the cited standard-of-care proposition.
*King v. G & M Realty Corp.*, 373 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “We think the measure of the landlord’s responsibility to the tenant with respect to common areas left in the landlord’s control should not differ in kind from that owed by the landlord to the tenant’s visitors… In the present context the tenant is not different from the visitor except as he may the more readily have or be chargeable with knowledge of a dangerous condition of a common area… The trial judge was thus correct in charging the jury as he did.”
